Participate in the naha con-pulling festival This is the first time
this 500-year-old traditional event has been held again since the
covid-19 pandemic. About 20,000 people
directly participated in this year's competition. The
contestants were divided  divided into two teams, the East team
and the West team, very similar. The audience came to cheer for
this year's competition using a
tow rope recognized by Guinness as the
world's largest D rope, its length is
about 200 m and the mass is  40 tons
before the competition starts the
participants will work together to push the rope into the right
position and tie it with a piece of wood
then the competition will last for 30 minutes
resulting in the largest team winning in the
minutes  The end of the Naha tug-of-war festival is the
world's largest tug-of-war competition to commemorate
the destruction of the city of Naha during the
great American invasion on October 10,
1944. The event is also seen as a

awarded the economics prize
to Professor Loria Gordin of
Harvard University, USA. She was awarded for
improving the world's understanding of the impact
of  Women and the labor market
Ms. Goldin, 77, is an
economic historian and labor economist. She
produced the first comprehensive report on
women's earnings and
labor market participation over many years.
Her century of research not only revealed
new trends, discovered the causes of
change, but also pointed to the
main causes of gender inequality. Ms.
Golden searched archives and
collected data.  Data for more than 200 years from the United States
in which she demonstrates the nature and reasons
why gender differences in
income and employment rates have changed
over time according to the Nobel Committee
said globally is available.  About 50% of
women are participating in the labor market,
the ratio is 80% for men.
However, women are currently paid lower wages
and also have fewer opportunities for career advancement
than men. Ms.
